entry.title: Kinjirō Ashiwara (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Kinjirō Ashiwara (pictured), a self-proclaimed emperor, initially called himself a shogun?

entry.title: Huntsville, Alabama (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Huntsville, Alabama, is nicknamed Rocket City?

entry.title: J. Howard Crocker (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Canadian pentathlon champion J. Howard Crocker introduced volleyball to China?

entry.title: Tarsus çatalburun (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the nose of the Tarsus çatalburun, a scenthound native to Turkey, is separated by a deep indentation or cleft, often creating the illusion of having two noses?

entry.title: Micro Star v. FormGen Inc. (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Micro Star v. FormGen Inc. affirmed that copyright owners have the exclusive right to make sequels?

entry.title: fictional religions (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that fictional religions, often described in speculative fiction, have in some cases inspired real religious movements?

entry.title: Gordon Coutts (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Scottish painter Gordon Coutts left Australia without paying maintenance to his estranged wife, but was arrested in New Zealand?

entry.title: the beat goes on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the beat goes on and on and on and on and on and on and on and on?
